body:
That's an interesting one since the [javadoc for HashSet `contains`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/HashSet.html#contains-java.lang.Object-) states:
```
Returns true if this set contains the specified element. More formally, returns true if and only if this set contains an element e such that (o==null ? e==null : o.equals(e)).
```
It turns out that the set in your example contains `date` as per this successful assertion: 
```java
assertThat(hashSet.iterator().next().equals(date)).isTrue();
```
I quickly searched online but could not find whether `HashSet.contains` implementation is considered a bug or just the javadoc which is wrong.

AssertJ actually looks into the collection to state whether an element is contained or not, this is why the assertions does not fail. 

Is that the desired behavior  ? On one hand user would expect AssertJ `contains` assertion to follow `contains` but on the other hand the set actually contains the given element. No clear winner.

I believe the real problem is that one should just not change elements added to a Set, this is a bad practice.

I'm not yet convinced to change that, I'd like to hear opinions.
@PascalSchumacher WDYT ?

Thank you for your fast reply. I think there is an inconsistency between JavaDoc of `HashSet#contains` and the method implementation. `HashSet#contains` is just delegating the call to its internal HashMap. On this `containsKey()` is called, in there the objects hash is build and with this `getNode` is called. So I think the JavaDoc there is misleading. 

But I also think, there are many usecases where you implement your own equals and hashcode methods and maybe you want to change fields, which are used in this methods. 

For sure we should tell the oracle developers that the JavaDoc is not correct, because there is no equals operations directly on the `HashSet#contains`-method. I will open a bugreport on the JDK. If you don¬¥t want to change your api behavior, maybe you can leave a comment on your code? :-)

I am not sure if this is an actual bug in JDK. See [this SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8805807/workaround-for-hash-for-a-hashset-when-the-internal-object-changes) that actually searches for a workaround for changing hash of an object.

The JavaDoc of `HashSet#contains` is correct, as it uses `HashMap#contains` and it uses equals. However, in `HasMap` and `HashSet` implementations `equals` is used only when there is a hash collision. In this case there is no object that matches the new hash.

The reason why this inconsistence exists in AssertJ is that everything is reduced down to an `Iterable`, which is then iterated and an `equals` check is done to check that an object is contained or not. Maybe we need to check if an `Iterable` is actually a `Collection` and call the collection specific methods for that. This way we can be sure that the correct JDK expectations are used.

And finally I also agree with @joel-costigliola one should not change hash of elements added to a `HashSet` and `HashMap`, as it can lead to a lot of inconsistent behaviour.

I think there is no clean way to fix this.

If we would change AssertJ to use `Collection#equals` we fix this case but break other cases, as AssertJ use the registered `ComparisonStrategy` (`StandardComparisonStrategy` by default, which compares arrays by their contents) to compare the elements contained in the `Iterable`.

I agree that changing the hashcode of elements added to a `HashSet` seems like a bad practice.
Still haven't made my mind, will give it more time.

Yeah, that's a point, we might go for the change and follow the Java HashSet behavior which is the main argument for me.
PR welcome, with all the people liking this issue it should be easy to find contributors ;-), let me know if one of you want to contribute I need to think at the best approach first (likely defining HashSet or Set specific assertions).

issue.title: Built-in comparator not used for SortedSet implementations

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary

Assertions on implementations of `SortedSet` (like `TreeSet`) do not use the comparator used to construct the instance.

#### Example

If I wanted to create a class that returned a set of strings which allowed testing for case-insensitive inclusion, I'd use a `TreeSet` with a custom comparator. The following code example is greatly simplified, but demonstrates the basic mechanics (in a real example, the creation of the set would be encapsulated within the class under test).

```java
TreeSet<String> mySet = new TreeSet<>(Comparator.comparing(String::toUpperCase));
mySet.add("FOO");
assertThat(mySet.contains("foo")).isTrue(); // passes
assertThat(mySet).contains("foo"); // fails
```

I found it surprising that the assertion didn't really call `mySet.contains()`, but looking into the AssertJ codebase I found that it was highly abstracted.

I can work around it by passing in an element comparator, like this:

```java
assertThat(mySet).usingElementComparator(mySet.comparator()).contains("foo")
```

However, in a real application, the set would probably have come from a method just returning `Set<String>`, so accessing its comparator is mostly out of the question. And even if I did, it just wouldn't feel like I was actually testing that my class returned a case-insensitive set.

body: @nach-o-man any update on this ? (it's alright if you are too busy to work on it).
@joel-costigliola haven't che—Åked it really cause didnt have time. As of right now I will start looking.
@joel-costigliola couldn't really find good solution... Will be leaving for vacation untill 24.05 so if anyone feels like grabbing it...
@nach-o-man no problem, thanks for the time you have spent!
